                  May / Mai / Mayo de 2023

                    Anglais A : littérature
                     Inglés A: Literatura

        Niveau supérieur et niveau moyen
           Nivel Superior y Nivel Medio

                  Paper / Épreuve / Prueba 1

                                               –3–             M23/1/AXENG/BP1/ENG/TZ2/XX/M


General marking instructions

 These notes to examiners are intended only as guidelines to assist marking. They are not offered
 as an exhaustive and fixed set of features which all answers must include.

 Answers which do not follow the approach suggested in the guiding question, but have provided
 an alternative formal or technical focus should be rewarded appropriately in line with the
 assessment criteria.


Instructions générales pour la notation

 Ces notes ne sont que simples lignes directrices pour aider les examinateurs lors de la notation.
 Elles ne peuvent en aucun cas être considérées comme un ensemble fixe et exhaustif de
 caractéristiques que les réponses doivent présenter.

 Les réponses qui ne suivent pas l’approche suggérée dans la question d’orientation, mais qui
 ont adopté un autre angle technique ou formel doivent être récompensées de manière
 appropriée, conformément aux critères d’évaluation.


Instrucciones generales para la corrección

 El objetivo de estas notas para los examinadores es servir de directrices a fin de ayudar en la
 corrección. No deben considerarse un conjunto fijo y exhaustivo de características que deban
 estar presentes en todas las respuestas.

 Las respuestas que no sigan el enfoque recomendado en la pregunta de orientación, pero
 posean un enfoque alternativo, de carácter formal o técnico, también deberán ser valoradas
 de acuerdo con los criterios de evaluación.
                                                 –4–             M23/1/AXENG/BP1/ENG/TZ2/XX/M


1.

                                            Literary form

                                           Prose (Fiction)

                           Elements of the text significant for analysis

     ●   creation of an atmosphere of languid, calm relaxation inside the house after Sunday
         lunch – resting, trickles of conversation, patches of silence - but be ready to credit other
         interpretations of type of atmosphere created
     ●   comparison/contrast with the atmosphere outside in the streets of Calcutta
     ●   the use of more familiar and reassuring household objects adding to the atmosphere –
         old radio, attachment to old clock which runs ten minutes fast, furniture, settling dust
     ●   the use of the mundane nature of radio advertisements conveyed as if by the local
         babbling idiot (humour)
     ●   positive, even humorous imagery such as the “festive crackle” and the women falling
         asleep – grown-ups as children; and negative imagery such as the dust everywhere,
         inside and outside, and the decaying buildings
     ●   the characterisation of Sandeep and his observation of the household, and how this
         connects to the atmosphere created
     ●   effect of the unsettling diction choices on the atmosphere (“mournful”, “drowning”, “scar”,
         “trenches”, “bombed out”)
     ●   brief mention of threat of looming Monday
     ●   exploration of why Chhotomama might be “sighing regretfully”
     ●   sense of security and familiarity – newspaper over face – falling asleep
     ●   the use of auditory imagery, such as the mournful song on the radio
     ●   sense of futility and/or passivity created by the details of activity/inactivity outside
     ●   the chaotic and random nature of the city as exemplified by the senseless work of
         modern art.
                                                –5–              M23/1/AXENG/BP1/ENG/TZ2/XX/M


2.

                                            Literary form

                                               Poetry

                           Elements of the text significant for analysis

     ●   the initial sense of achievement/reward at the end of a long walk – (“Downhill...” “rest…
         sweetest thing...”), leading to...
     ●   the sense of satisfaction in the narrator over the first six lines, and the creation of his
         sense of security
     ●   the use of shifts in tone (e.g. from positive to negative) to communicate the poetic
         persona’s change in feelings (e.g. from line 8 onwards)
     ●   the imagery used to create the poet’s situation (e.g. cold, heat, tiredness)
     ●   the use of contrasts, particularly in the first and final stanzas
     ●   the succinct accumulation of detail in the first two lines of stanza two
     ●   the way the narration unfolds… (end of the walk, arrival at the inn, sense of security)
     ●   … striking a new note with the owl’s melancholy cry
     ●   the symbolic value of the owl, and acknowledgement of how the owl’s cry leads to a shift
         in tone
     ●   why the poet moves from talking of the owl’s “cry” to its “voice”
     ●   why the poet might have chosen the word “escaped”
     ●   the significance of the use of “salted” - a good or bad thing, or simply giving the food a
         different/seasoned taste?
     ●   the effect of rhyme and its impact on tone (or alternative point of entry)
     ●   the rhythm of the poem and its effects on tone (e.g. the first two lines)
     ●   the able candidate might notice and comment upon the use of iambic pentameter and
         where and to what effect that iambic rhythm is disrupted
     ●   the effect of the alliteration in the final stanza and its impact on tone, or other point of
         entry
     ●   a comment on the way the persona’s feelings are expressed in the final six lines,
         perhaps showing his humanity, or even guilt at his security, and how the double meaning
         in “salted” suggests both guilt and empathy
     ●   the ambivalence of the final word “rejoice” and its significance in the poetic persona's
         reflections
     ●   the impact of the word “all” in the final stanza (soldiers and poor)
     ●   the way the persona’s voice is characterized through the use of diction and its impact on
         tone
